name: LargeNumberMath
tagline: A C# library for performing maths on super-duper large numbers.
body: # Welcome to the LargeNumberMath C# Library ## Usage Of The Library For the addition method: ``` $ string result = objName.Add("firstNum", "secondNum", false); ``` For the subtraction method: ``` $ string result = objName.Subtract("firstNum", "secondNum", false); ``` *Please note that the bool present in the 'Add()' and 'Subtract()' is optional. If you know that the numbers that are going to be parsed into the function will be positive, then you can set this to true for performance purposes. For the multipication method: ``` $ string result = objName.Multiply("firstNum", intNum); ``` For calculating factorials (input number must be larger than 0): ``` $ string result = objName.Factorial(intNum); ``` Upon addition of more content, the README and this page will be updated. ## Newbie's Guide After [importing](https://github.com/galacticfan/LargeNumberMath/wiki/Usage-and-Installation-of-the-DLL) your DLL and referencing the library, you are then ready to begin using the supplied methods. To start, you will need to create an object of the class `LNMath` by doing the following: ``` $ LNMath nameOfObject = new LNMath(); ``` Then, using the object that you just created, you can access the methods within the library such as the `Add()` method. ``` $ string result = nameOfObject.Add("firstNumber", "secondNumber"); ``` Please note that the methods within the library are designed to take in numbers in the form of strings so that there is no limit in the size of calculation.
